body:
I think what @MarcoFalke suggested here: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17094#issuecomment-561194286 is a good idea,
this can be a way also for contributors to subscribe to PRs touching specific parts of the code,
that way they can know if something might conflict with their PRs or they can know when there's something they feel comfortable reviewing.

I do wonder though how it will look like when each folder might have a long list of people,
Although if it's a problem we maybe could use githubs teams feature, and create teams like `validation`, `crypto`, `p2p`, `wallet` etc. and subscribe those teams and then add people to the teams accordingly, but maybe that's an overkill.
The rapidcheck documentation was recently removed along with rapidcheck itself.
diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,101 @@
+# ==============================================================================
+#                          Bitcoin Core CODEOWNERS
+# ==============================================================================
+
+# Configuration of code ownership and review approvals for the bitcoin/bitcoin
+# repo.
+
+# Order is important; the last matching pattern takes the most precedence.
+# More info on how this file works can be found at:
+# https://help.github.com/articles/about-codeowners/
+
+# This file is called CODEOWNERS because it is a magic file for GitHub to
+# automatically suggest reviewers. In this project's case, the names below
+# should be thought of as code reviewers rather than owners. Regular
+# contributors are free to add their names to specific directories or files
+# provided that they are willing to provide a review when automatically
+# assigned.
+
+# Information on the decision making process for pull requests can be found
+# in the "Decision Making Process" section of the CONTRIBUTING.md doc.
+
+
+# Maintainers
+#   @laanwj
+#   @sipa
+#   @fanquake
+#   @jonasschnelli
+#   @marcofalke
+#   @meshcollider
+
+
+# Build system
+/configure.ac                       @dongcarl
+/build-aux/                         @dongcarl
+/depends/                           @dongcarl
+*.am                                @dongcarl
+Makefile.*                          @dongcarl
+
+# Test framework
+/src/test/                          @marcofalke
+/test/                              @marcofalke
+/ci/                                @marcofalke
+
+# Fuzzing
+/src/test/fuzz/                     @practicalswift
+/doc/fuzzing.md                     @practicalswift
+
+# GUI
+/src/qt/                            @jonasschnelli
+
+# Wallet
+/src/wallet/                        @meshcollider
+
+# Descriptors
+*descriptor*                        @achow101 @sipa
+
+# MSVC build system
+/build_msvc/                        @sipsorcery
+
+# scripts/linter
+*.sh                                @practicalswift
+/test/lint/                         @practicalswift
+/ci/lint/                           @practicalswift
+
+# Bech32
+/src/bech32.*                       @sipa
+/src/bench/bech32.*                 @sipa
+
+# PSBT
+/src/psbt*                          @achow101
+/src/node/psbt*                     @achow101
+/doc/psbt.md                        @achow101
+
+# Consensus
+/src/consensus/                     @sipa
+/src/consensus/tx_verify.*          @jtimon
+/src/consensus/validation.h         @TheBlueMatt
+/src/consensus/tx_check.*           @jnewbery
+
+# Docs
+/doc/Doxyfile.in                     @fanquake
+/doc/JSON-RPC-interface.md           @harding
+/doc/REST-interface.md               @jonasschnelli
+/doc/benchmarking.md                 @ariard
+/doc/bitcoin-conf.md                 @hebasto
+/doc/build-freebsd.md                @fanquake
+/doc/build-netbsd.md                 @fanquake
+/doc/build-openbsd.md                @laanwj
+/doc/build-osx.md                    @fanquake
+/doc/build-unix.md                   @laanwj
+/doc/build-windows.md                @laanwj
+/doc/dependencies.md                 @fanquake
+/doc/developer-notes.md              @laanwj
+/doc/files.md                        @hebasto
+/doc/gitian-building.md              @laanwj
+/doc/productivity.md                 @dongcarl
+/doc/rapidcheck.md                   @jonatack

body: Ah, thanks. This section currently serves as an example of what is possible, but your comment also illustrates the point in the PR description that the downside of a detailed CODEOWNERS file is that it will require more attention and updates.
diff_hunk:

body: Could be worth trying but I'll defer to the maintainers. IIUC this would be a guideline/suggestion and not a limiter, but I'm not sure LOC "contributed" is a great metric. Review time spent on the codebase and willingness to invest time reviewing a particular PR may both be factors as well, but which would not be accounted for. Also, PRs can be improved by repeated rounds of reviewing but in the end only the PR author is taken into account in the LOC stats. It may be good for these factors to be stated if this file is intended to be a reference for new contributors. A final question is if the updating and maintainance effort would be worth the value added.

> your comment also illustrates the point in the PR description that the downside of a detailed CODEOWNERS file is that it will require more attention and updates.

Agreed. It may be good for someone to be nominated/dedicated to this.

body: ("contributed" in quotes also because sometimes a refactoring or code move changes the git history to look like the latest committer wrote the code, but I digress... this all just means that active updating and judgement might be important)

I would underscore this point even further, like "Not being among the list of potential reviewers shouldn't be as a discouragement for not reviewing. A wide range of careful reviews by contributors from different levels of experience is likely to make the PR more robust as people look at a more diverse aspects of code change".
